keyTakeAways: Thieves used a vehicle-mounted mechanical lift and battery-powered disc cutters to breach the Louvre's Gallery of Apollo, gaining access via a balcony near the River Seine.
The gang stole eight 19th-century royal jewellery items, including diadems, necklaces, earrings, and brooches, all of which are of priceless heritage value and contain thousands of diamonds.
Two items, including Empress Eugénie's crown, were reportedly dropped during the escape and are being examined for damage.
The museum's localised alarm was reportedly broken or disactivated; however, the wider security system did activate, and staff followed protocol.
The robbers fled on two scooters and were described as experienced, possibly acting under criminal organisation orders.
Investigators believe the stolen items will be broken up and sold in parts to extract value, with experts warning of potential melting and recutting of materials.

The theft has triggered a political backlash in France, with President Emmanuel Macron calling it an 'attack on our history' and other political figures condemning it as a 'humiliation' or 'wound to the French soul'.
The Louvre remains closed, with visitors who booked tickets being automatically refunded, and security measures like metal barriers and police presence have been increased.
This incident is part of a recent uptick in museum thefts in France, including prior heists at the Cognacq-Jay, Hieron, and Adrien Dubouche museums.

The Louvre previously requested government help for renovation and security upgrades under the 'New Renaissance' project, which includes €700 million to €800 million in investment and enhanced security measures.

summaryOfNewsArticle: A brazen heist occurred at the Louvre Museum in Paris on Sunday, between 09:30 and 09:40 local time, when four armed thieves used a vehicle-mounted ladder and battery-powered disc cutters to breach the Gallery of Apollo, stealing eight 19th-century royal jewellery items, including diadems and necklaces. The thieves, described as experienced and well-organized, fled on two scooters, with two items, including Empress Eugénie’s crown, reportedly dropped during escape. A preliminary report notes that one in three rooms in the raided area lacked CCTV, and the localised alarm was reportedly broken, though the wider system activated. The incident has sparked national outrage, with political leaders condemning it as a blow to France’s cultural identity. Authorities suspect a criminal group was involved, and investigators are analyzing CCTV footage. Experts warn the stolen items will likely be broken and sold in parts. The theft follows a recent spate of museum thefts in France, including at the Cognacq-Jay, Hieron, and Adrien Dubouche museums. The Louvre remains closed, with visitors refunded and enhanced security measures in place. The incident has reignited discussions about the need for improved museum security, including the long-planned New Renaissance renovation project with €700 million to €800 million in investment.
